Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Understanding Intermittent Water Sources and Impacts on Fish to Design Optimal Water Conservation Strategies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A major question in water resources is how to provide water for human uses while maintaining streamflow that sustains riverine ecosystems and fisheries. Intermittent streams, which provide habitat for salmonid fishes and water resources for agriculture, dry up into a series of disconnected pools in the late summer. To alleviate pressure on rivers and conserve habitat for juvenile salmon on the brink of extinction, communities are increasingly examining water conservation alternatives such as rainwater harvesting and groundwater recharge. Recent pilot projects provide a timely and unprecedented opportunity to address interdisciplinary questions about linkages among environmental variables, ecosystem services, and optimal management of increasingly scarce water resources. This project is expected to produce novel contributions to fundamental science, including understanding processes related to fish survival and the interactions among carbon decomposition, streamflow, and sediment transport in intermittent streams. By relating salmonid survival to predictable environmental characteristics and creating a better understanding of these critical variables, the research findings are likely to have applicability to seasonally dry watersheds region-and nation-wide. The project will facilitate mutually beneficial interactions between scientists and multiple stakeholder groups, who will also benefit from new e-tools for managing their natural resources. Findings will be disseminated through scholarly publications and at regional symposia as well as through documents developed for stakeholders and a citizen science web portal.

This project specifically addresses a fundamental knowledge gap: what habitat conditions cause salmonids to disappear from some pools during the summer dry period? This project builds on a two-year field study in two tributaries of Salmon Creek (Sonoma Co., CA): Tannery Creek, which flows throughout the summer, and Fay Creek, which tends to dry into a series of isolated pools. Through extensive sampling in these adjacent streams, this research will test the hypothesis that accumulation of organic material in poorly flushed pools drives declining dissolved oxygen associated with a subsequent loss of salmonids. Fish surveys in the two tributaries will be paired with measurements of temperature, dissolved oxygen, water depth and velocity, pool volume, and organic carbon concentrations and quality. More intensive studies, focused on monitoring how these attributes change as the stream dries and determining which aquifers sustain sanctuary pools, will be conducted in four study river segments. Using linear mixing models, this research will quantify groundwater contributions and flowpaths to pools that provide critical refugia for salmon, and identify aquifers that should be targeted for enhanced infiltration. This work will also evaluate how rainwater harvesting will impact salmonid habitat with and without managed groundwater recharge. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career. Increased understanding of interactions between groundwater and streamflow will enable residents and resource conservation districts to target water conservation and rainwater harvesting projects where they will yield the greatest benefit to stream ecosystems. Scientists working on salmonid recovery will benefit from increased access to local knowledge and observations via facilitated collaborative workshops and project-developed citizen science dissemination tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intermittent coastal streams along western North America play a vital but under-studied role in providing rearing habitat for juvenile salmonid fishes. In intermittent streams, juvenile salmonids occupy isolated pools during the dry season. While intermittent reaches may be a source for salmonid populations following wet winters (“boom” years) because of their high productivity and abundant spawning habitat, those same reaches may become population sinks in years when drought or human water diversion results in extreme contraction and poor water quality (“bust” years). Although salmonids have adapted to climate variability and can thrive in intermittent reaches, they can also experience high mortality in dry years.

                   

Previous studies have identified threshold levels of temperature and DO for salmonid mortality, but none have studied these metrics in combination with flow in intermittent streams. Clearly, flow affects several factors that might influence salmonid survival, but how hydrologic and geomorphic attributes affect patterns of salmonid survival in intermittent streams remains a significant question, with implications for how we manage these streams in a changing climate. Our study focuses on a comparative analysis of flow and habitat factors that influence survival of coho salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) and steelhead trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) in two coastal California streams (Fay and Tannery creeks, tributaries to Salmon Creek, Sonoma County) across a gradient of intermittency from continuously flowing to nearly dry, including through deepening drought conditions.

           

Our work involved state, federal, and university scientists as well as local residents, who co-developed a wet-dry mapping project to survey the stream each year, and who volunteered their wells and springs for sampling for hydrologic sampling. The hydrologic sampling approach we used involves measuring dissolved organic carbon (from leaf litter, microbial activity, and algae) and the ratios of stable isotopes of hydrogen and oxygen in the water molecules themselves. This method identifies the influence of groundwater, surface water, and hyporheic (below the streambed) flow on dissolved oxygen levels in pools during the dry summer. This approach is extensible to a wide range of other watersheds. Within ecology, we provide new recognition that coho salmon, a federally threatened species, is dependent on groundwater inflows in at least some intermittent streams. Our work has also demonstrated that, within intermittent stream pools, coho salmon and steelhead trout occupy distinct niches and may be limited by dissolved oxygen concentrations and pool geomorphology, respectively. In these streams, groundwater inflow is needed to maintain adequate levels of dissolved oxygen for coho salmon through the summer dry period. We show that groundwater sources, however, are spatially and temporally dynamic, and have the potential to diminish substantially during periods of extended drought.

 

This project reinvigorated collaborations among the local Salmon Creek Watershed Council (SCWC), the Gold Ridge Resource Conservation District (RCD), the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) Santa Rosa office, and the California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CA DFW). At collaborative workshops organized by co-PI Woelfle-Erskine, members of these groups initiated several new collaborative research projects, including Gold Ridge’s long term monitoring of a SCWC member’s well, NMFS and Gold Ridge staff participation in the SCWC wet-dry mapping effort, and CA DFW’s decision to incorporate the watershed into the long term Coastal Monitoring Program for coho salmon.


With recent passage of the Sustainable Groundwater Management Act, counties in California are now tasked with developing plans for managing their groundwater resources. Meanwhile, water resource agencies within the state are increasingly implementing standards for ecological flows in their regulation of surface water. Our work identifies a gap within each of these management issues: groundwater has not, to date, entered into the conversation about ecological flows, while recognition of groundwater-dependent ecosystems or organisms that occupy surface habitat have not yet entered into conversations about sustainable management of groundwater. Our work has the potential to inform active policy development in both of these areas.
